BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of the occasionally strong wind, fresh snow drift accumulations will form in the course of the day. These can be released by a single winter sport participant in particular on north, northeast and east facing slopes above approximately 2200 m. Caution is to be exercised at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack.
In the regions with a lot of snow and on very steep sunny slopes more small and medium-sized dry and moist avalanches are to be expected as a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: In some cases the wind slabs have bonded still only poorly with each other and the old snowpack. Over a wide area new snow and wind slabs are lying on soft layers. Individual weak layers exist in the snowpack on wind-loaded slopes. In particular at elevated altitudes snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence at intermediate and high altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of the occasionally strong wind, fresh snow drift accumulations will form in the course of the day. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls above approximately 2200 m and at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack. Wind slabs can be released, even by a single winter sport participant and reach large size in isolated cases.
In particular on very steep sunny slopes and in steep rocky terrain more medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large dry and moist avalanches are possible as a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: In some cases the wind slabs have bonded still only poorly with the old snowpack. At elevated altitudes snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind. At low altitude only a small amount of snow is lying for the time of year.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The wind slabs of last week are clearly recognisable. These represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant above the tree line. The fresh wind slabs are clearly recognisable. They are to be avoided as far as possible. Caution is to be exercised in all aspects in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. The number and size of avalanche prone locations will increase with altitude.

In addition further very occasional gliding avalanches are possible, in particular on steep east, south and west facing slopes below approximately 2600 m. In isolated cases the gliding avalanches are quite large, in particular in the regions with a lot of snow. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The fresh wind slabs are lying on surface hoar in some places. The somewhat older wind slabs are lying on soft layers. They are unlikely to be released now.
Towards its base, the snowpack is largely stable. Snow depths vary greatly above the tree line, depending on the infuence of the wind. The snowpack will be subject to considerable local variations.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The large surface-area wind slabs remain in some cases prone to triggering.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh wind slabs at intermediate and high altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of northwesterly wind, sometimes avalanche prone wind slabs will form. The fresh wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in some cases in particular on north to northeast to southeast facing aspects and generally at intermediate and high altitudes. The more recent wind slabs are to be bypassed in very steep terrain.
In particular in the regions with a lot of snow and on sunny slopes more small and medium-sized dry and moist avalanches are possible as a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation. These can occur in particular in starting zones where no previous releases have taken place.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The snowpack will be well bonded below approximately 2000 m.
In isolated cases new snow is lying on a hard crust. In all regions only a small amount of snow is lying for the time of year.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The clearly visible wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of new snow and a moderate to strong wind from northwesterly directions, wind slabs will form in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas as well as at high altitude.
The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on very steep slopes above approximately 2400 m, and adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls.
Fresh wind slabs are mostly easy to recognise but to be assessed with care and prudence. They can be released by a single winter sport participant in some cases.
In particular in steep rocky terrain and on extremely steep sunny slopes only isolated mostly small dry and moist avalanches are possible as a consequence of solar radiation.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
10 cm of snow, and up to 20 cm in some localities, has fallen since Monday above approximately 2000 m.
Over a wide area new snow and wind slabs are lying on a hard crust. In its middle, the snowpack is fairly homogeneous.
Snow depths vary greatly at high altitude, depending on the infuence of the wind. The wind slabs have bonded generally well with the old snowpack.
Especially on steep sunny slopes only a little snow is lying. Also adjacent to ridgelines hardly any snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The avalanche danger will persist. As a consequence of a moderate to strong northwesterly wind, further wind slabs will form in the course of the day.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence. As a consequence of solar radiation the avalanche prone locations will become more prevalent.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: By Sunday wind slabs will form in particular adjacent to ridgelines. The fresh wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in some cases at elevated altitudes. At high altitude the avalanche prone locations are more prevalent.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: As a consequence of wind, clearly visible wind slabs will form. In some places wind slabs are lying on soft layers. Moist snow slides are possible below approximately 2000 m. In particular at low altitude a little snow is lying.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Snow sport activities outside marked and open pistes call for experience in the assessment of avalanche danger and caution. On shady slopes a moderate danger of dry avalanches will persist.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The new snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Wind slabs can in some places be released by large loads and reach medium size. The avalanche prone locations for dry avalanches are to be found in particular at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack, when entering gullies and bowls for example and on very steep shady slopes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The wind slabs of last week are clearly recognisable. They represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
In particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls visible wind slabs formed. In particular on very steep slopes more mostly small avalanches are possible.
Avalanches can be released, mostly by large loads.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The meteorological conditions will foster a strengthening of the snowpack.
Below approximately 1500 m only a little snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The weather will be sunny at times.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in some cases above the tree line. This also applies in areas close to the tree line. The mostly small wind slabs are clearly recognisable to the trained eye. They are to be avoided as far as possible. Gullies and bowls are especially unfavourable. Even a small avalanche can sweep winter sport participants along and give rise to falls.

In addition further very occasional gliding avalanches are possible, in particular on steep east, south and west facing slopes below approximately 2600 m. In isolated cases the gliding avalanches are quite large, in particular in the regions with a lot of snow. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
As a consequence of a sometimes strong wind from northwesterly directions, further wind slabs will form in the course of the day. The fresh wind slabs are lying on surface hoar in some places. These are mostly rather small but can in some cases be released easily. The somewhat older wind slabs are unlikely to be released now.

Towards its base, the snowpack is largely stable. Snow depths vary greatly above the tree line, depending on the infuence of the wind. The snowpack will be subject to considerable local variations.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The fresh wind slabs remain in some cases prone to triggering.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Snow sport activities outside marked and open pistes call for a certain restraint. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on steep shady slopes at elevated altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The new snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The avalanche prone locations for dry avalanches are to be found in particular at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack, when entering gullies and bowls for example and on very steep shady slopes. Wind slabs can be released, mostly by large loads and reach large size in isolated cases.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The clearly visible wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of new snow and a moderate to strong wind from northwesterly directions, wind slabs will form in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas as well as at high altitude.
Along the border between Valais and France Here the avalanche prone locations are more prevalent and larger.
The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on very steep slopes above approximately 2200 m, and adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls.
Fresh wind slabs are mostly easy to recognise but to be assessed with care and prudence. They can be released by a single winter sport participant in some cases.
In particular in steep rocky terrain and on extremely steep sunny slopes only isolated mostly small dry and moist avalanches are possible as a consequence of solar radiation.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
10 to 15 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since Monday above approximately 2000 m.
Over a wide area new snow and wind slabs are lying on a hard crust. In its middle, the snowpack is fairly homogeneous.
Snow depths vary greatly at high altitude, depending on the infuence of the wind. The wind slabs have bonded generally well with the old snowpack.
Especially on steep sunny slopes below approximately 2100 m only a little snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The avalanche danger will persist. As a consequence of a moderate to strong northwesterly wind, further wind slabs will form in the course of the day.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence. As a consequence of solar radiation the avalanche prone locations will become more prevalent.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
By Sunday wind slabs will form in particular adjacent to ridgelines. The fresh wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in some cases at elevated altitudes. The fresh wind slabs are clearly recognisable. They are to be avoided as far as possible. At high altitude the avalanche prone locations are more prevalent.
In addition further very occasional gliding avalanches are possible, in particular on steep east, south and west facing slopes below approximately 2600 m. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: As a consequence of wind, clearly visible wind slabs will form. In some places wind slabs are lying on soft layers. Moist snow slides are possible below approximately 2000 m. In particular at low altitude a little snow is lying.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The wind slabs of last week are clearly recognisable. They represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: In particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls visible wind slabs formed. Especially on wind-loaded slopes more small and, in isolated cases, medium-sized avalanches are possible. Avalanches can be released, mostly by large loads.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: In some cases new snow and wind slabs are lying on the smooth surface of an old snowpack. Weak layers exist in the snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The weather will be sunny at times.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The old snowpack will be quite favourable.
The fresh snow and the wind slabs that are forming above all adjacent to ridgelines in all aspects represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The fresh snow and the mostly small wind slabs can still be released in some cases in particular on steep, little used north, northeast and northwest facing slopes above approximately 2000 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The old snowpack will be favourable at intermediate and high altitudes. In particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls as well as at high altitude mostly small wind slabs will form.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The wind slabs can be released in isolated cases, especially at their margins. Caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. Mostly avalanches are small.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The wind slabs are lying on soft layers. The old snowpack will be quite stable.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Individual weak layers exist in the snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Avalanches are not to be expected.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The snowpack is not distinctly layered. The weather conditions will foster a stabilisation of the weak layers in all aspects. Avalanches are not to be expected.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The wind slabs can be released in isolated cases, especially at their margins. Caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. Mostly avalanches are small.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The wind slabs are lying on soft layers. The old snowpack will be quite stable.
